document.title: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards for Mathematics

4559449E2D1848228C4139797552F22A.description: Analyze decisions and strategies using probability concepts.

E30C688943F846968015274E0C9AE447.description:
Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions. Use probabilities to make
fair decisions.

FAD59A3FFE9E45EE8DCECB6B0A9DDF2A.description:
Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions by finding expected values
and determine if decisions are fair.

B3563A57D7834493A5D22EC1993B20C8.description:
Construct and compare theoretical and experimental probability distributions
and use those distributions to find expected values.

AE0ACB5367AB4A1CA778F72E22C5F37A.description:
Calculate the expected value of a random variable as the mean of its probability
distribution. Find expected values by assigning probabilities to payoff values.
Use expected values to evaluate and compare strategies in real-world scenarios.

1DD360E918AC42CCA4E365F95AD3098B.description:
Develop the probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample
space in which a theoretical probability can be calculated and graph the
distribution.

81A0AD680A7946EC9786B80C4CE2275F.description:
Create residual plots and analyze those plots to compare the fit of linear,
quadratic, and exponential models to a given data set. Select the appropriate
model and use it for interpolation.

5F5F4F4B63D347339CBF89D6505FC50E.description:
Differentiate between correlation and causation when describing the
relationship between two variables. Identify potential lurking variables which
may explain an association between two variables.

B51F2FD048994F3F846BC614DA5A0F86.description:
Compute using technology and interpret the correlation coefficient of a linear
fit

7FEABD73B16648F4BDCC8F155FEEC9F2.description:
Find linear models using median fit and regression methods to make
predictions. Interpret the slope and intercept of a linear model in the context of
the data.

DB24BDE20B384F1799C198BE133A8C02.description:
Using technology, create scatterplots and analyze those plots to compare the fit
of linear, quadratic, or exponential models to a given data set. Select the
appropriate model, fit a function to the data set, and use the function to solve
problems in the context of the data.

816B35A4F7C74EB1AD6356B4B5163CD5.description:
Analyze bivariate categorical data using two-way tables and identify possible
associations between the two categories using marginal, joint, and conditional
frequencies.

E3F335685F7F41DDB00C75EC5C0376B2.description:
Use the mean and standard deviation of a data set to fit it to a normal
distribution and to estimate population percentages. Recognize that there are
data sets for which such a procedure is not appropriate. Use calculators,
spreadsheets, and tables to estimate areas under the normal curve.

5D49C51EA07D4AB8A2FA36F5556B914D.description:
Summarize and represent data from a single data set. Interpret differences in
shape, center, and spread in the context of the data set, accounting for possible
effects of extreme data points (outliers).

D4BCD39B311A4E98BCEAB9E4C499D842.description:
Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center
and spread of two or more different data sets that include all real numbers.

2ECE5ACA63E6425B90EBA524D4E0B633.description:
Select and create an appropriate display, including dot plots, histograms, and
box plots, for data that includes only real numbers.

139B56BD996F498C96F73E8A639573A9.description:
Evaluate claims and conclusions in published reports or articles based on data by analyzing study
design and the collection, analysis, and display of the data.Â

829FC6C5FC5C43D0AE8A504B78C8D756.description:
Distinguish between experiments and observational studies. Determine which of two or more
possible experimental designs will best answer a given research question and justify the choice
based on statistical significance.

072A6AF1135F42E492680AB0CDFA9E7E.description:
Use data from a sample survey to estimate a population mean or proportion; develop a margin of
error through the use of simulation models for random sampling.

869AA6C61974458592993AFE79AA1223.description:
Plan and conduct a survey to answer a statistical question. Recognize how the plan addresses
sampling technique, randomization, measurement of experimental error and methods to reduce
bias.Â

A75A91B808404EB095D4CAB7786DED23.description:
Distinguish between experimental and theoretical probabilities. Collect data on a chance event
and use the relative frequency to estimate the theoretical probability of that event. Determine
whether a given probability model is consistent with experimental results.

B890D919152348F9825DBACA4B8DB59C.description:
Understand statistics and sampling distributions as a process for making inferences about
population parameters based on a random sample from that population.

BA9593D872764EF0B2DA71B93028D236.description:
Use permutations and combinations to solve mathematical and real-world problems, including
determining probabilities of compound events. Justify the results.

867E7A7CF8EA4E5BB75F97FA53E11011.description:
Apply the Addition Rule and the Multiplication Rule to determine probabilities, including
conditional probabilities, and interpret the results in terms of the probability model.

C93A9DF0A13B4B68873E99F3BA30E03A.description:
Calculate the conditional probability of an event A given event B as the fraction of Bâs outcomes
that also belong to A, and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

AF949A87229441C48FA313770C7C62C0.description:
Recognize and explain the concepts of conditional probability and independence in everyday
language and everyday situations.

59EE7672D2304692BD9475F4B9F360A6.description:
Construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data when two categories are associated
with each object being classified. Use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are
independent and to approximate conditional probabilities.

C9E046496CFB496387973AE5E4A878B5.description:
Understand the conditional probability of A given B as P(A and B)/P(B), and interpret
independence of A and B as saying that the conditional probability of A given B is the same as
the probability of A, and the conditional probability of B given A is the same as the probability
of B.

400B02BBB6DD47FDBD7E204001FA0D48.description:
Use the multiplication rule to calculate probabilities for independent and dependent events.
Understand that two events A and B are independent if the probability of A and B occurring
together is the product of their probabilities, and use this characterization to determine if they are
independent.

D946BB021DD44232952474EA651440D5.description: Represent sample spaces for compound events using Venn diagrams.

359D69E70BA34A619D98BA198A10A201.description: Relate intersections, unions, and complements to the words and, or, and not.Â

48B1AC9978A645E8A25DB2BE5CCD3B59.description: Use Venn diagrams to represent intersections, unions, and complements

3DFF934174334E8C923132E47DD9139D.description: Describe events as subsets of a sample space and

D4349D405E2045448CDE5EA3093E67C7.description: Conditional Probability and Rules of ProbabilityÂ
